author: Lucas Carson

text:
Of interest is how much Akari Kaida and Yoshino Aoki took inspiration from other games for some tracks in this game; and how they in turn composed songs for later games that sound quite close to Breath of Fire 3 tracks.
Both of the composers also sing for the closing credits song, and Yoshino Aoki sang Roll's theme in Marvel vs Capcom as well!

text: I replayed Breath of Fire I and II countless times, but never the PS1 games. Having played both 3 and 4 a long time ago shortly after their release, my memories of the games are getting fuzzier so I will have to fix that. I do remember prefering the SNES games which I love. For some reason, the intro to this theme reminds me of Mother 3.

text:
This game turns 20 this September! What better time to replay it? ‚ô•
It is a little janky, but I feel it's a strong contender for "best in the series". But that doesn't matter, what does is that it's a fun game with a rad battle system, memorable characters, and an intriguing plot.

author: Ryo hazuki

text: BoF III is great! It has some of the best spritework on the PSX, and the overall presentation of the music and visuals is remarkably cohesive and purposeful. A step above most RPGS, for sure. I think the designers had really locked in the idea of what BoF meant to them after the first couple games, and III has a really strong sense of personality because of that. It feels like a very real world exists inside the game, and it's mostly a wonderful relaxing one as this song suggests.
author: Margatroid

author: Ryo hazuki

text: Love 3 and 4 both, 4 has a truly incredible soundtrack though. Every track is immersive and there are amazing village themes like Landscape and Yet The Merchants Will Go, intense dungeon music like A Gods Beast and one of the best final boss themes I've ever heard A Raging Emperor's Banquet
author: Genkaku
